forkee.name: SignalR
forkee.description: Incredibly simple real-time web for ASP.NET Core

comment.body: Put the code in a GitHub repository and we'll take a look.

Thanks for the reply. I wrote some code that tries to connect and return a promise with the connection on success and an empty promise on fail and tries all different protocols until it has a connection. I think I wrote it ok, but an example would be great because I think lots of people want a fallback protocol. 

There are still some issues I experience, I will look into them and maybe the are because its just because its just production ready but maybe you can address these issues immediately.

- Internet explorer 11 works fine on websockets. On long polling it connects fine, but as soon as it get the first data from the hub, it keeps sending infinit connecting requests.
-  On azure, while I turned on websockets it keeps connecting using long polling.

issue.title: Simplify javascript client wire up to http
issue.body:
https://github.com/davidfowl/SignalRCoreAlphaSample/blob/350420c3b075c02e2ae31431e0f698072fcfe721/Sample/wwwroot/index.html#L9-L10


I think we're going to have to support defaulting the IConnection impl to HttpConnection in the javascript client.

Basically this:

https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/blob/eec4b33cff09382285766844b8054d3e65fa1131/client-ts/Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Client.TS/HubConnection.ts#L31

We accept string url or IConnection.

```typescript
 constructor(connection: IConnection | string, options: IHubConnectionOptions = {}) { 
```

On top of that, we should support relative paths that will default to document.blah (if available, we can just detect if there's a document and if not, throw for the nodejs scenario). Basically making it so we don't have to do this:

https://github.com/davidfowl/SignalRCoreAlphaSample/blob/350420c3b075c02e2ae31431e0f698072fcfe721/Sample/wwwroot/index.html#L9

Doing those 2 things will let us do:

```js
let connection = new signalR.HubConnection('/chat');
```

comment.body: We need this for the alpha.


On top of that, we should support relative paths that will default to document.blah (if available, we can just detect if there's a document and if not, throw for the nodejs scenario). Basically making it so we don't have to do this:

https://github.com/davidfowl/SignalRCoreAlphaSample/blob/350420c3b075c02e2ae31431e0f698072fcfe721/Sample/wwwroot/index.html#L9

Doing those 2 things will let us do:

```js
let connection = new signalR.HubConnection('/chat');
```

issue.title: No easy way to get the HttpContext from a HubConnectionContext
issue.body:
We added GetHttpContext on ConnectionContext but then we changed the Hub to expose HubConnectionContext instead of ConnectionContext:

https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/blob/eec4b33cff09382285766844b8054d3e65fa1131/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Sockets.Http/HttpConnectionContextExtensions.cs

This makes it harder to get at the HttpContext from inside of the hub. We should expose GetHttpContext on HubConnectionContext.

comment.body: We should fix this for the alpha /cc @moozzyk @muratg

issue.title: Issue with IConnection events returning a Task
Cannot build SignalR-rel-2.0.0
issue.body:
This is my first comment here, so first of all let me thank you all the hard work you put into this library!

The problem I encountered is that the version labeled with SignalR-rel-2.0.0 can not be built. I ran the build.cmd /t:Restore command, and it gave me the following output: 

[Output](https://gist.github.com/gabor182/d3279703f442cd23a5ceb2bbac46cbbf)

Where can these missing packages be found? If some additional package feeder is needed, then it would be wise to put its url into the readme file (or the build script could automatically update the package source list if a nuget.exe location is given in a command arg)
Is there any way to have a .NET Core 2.0 compatible version of SignalR?

comment.body: @KPixel as for versioning the product as 2.0.0 or 2.1.0 instead of 1.0.0, we'll discuss it after the alpha since it won't align with the ASP.NET core version right now anyways.

issue.title: Issue with IConnection events returning a Task

comment.body: Good catch! We'll fix this post alpha.

issue.title: No easy way to get the HttpContext from a HubConnectionContext
issue.body:
We added GetHttpContext on ConnectionContext but then we changed the Hub to expose HubConnectionContext instead of ConnectionContext:

https://github.com/aspnet/SignalR/blob/eec4b33cff09382285766844b8054d3e65fa1131/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Sockets.Http/HttpConnectionContextExtensions.cs

This makes it harder to get at the HttpContext from inside of the hub. We should expose GetHttpContext on HubConnectionContext.

comment.body:
@davidfowl 

Will there by MSSQL support in the alpha? e.g.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/signalr/overview/performance/scaleout-with-sql-server

In your sample app it looks like only a redis package is available at the moment.

Thanks!

issue.title: SSE transport times out behind IIS due to idle connection
issue.body: After 120 seconds of no messages through the SSE transport it will be closed by IIS as an idle connection. Adding keep-alives could fix this.

issue.title: Production use of SignalR for Asp.Net Core
issue.body:
Hello, 

I would like to ask about production use of SignalR. I want to use the SignalR in the production and is it possible use the latest version of SignalR for Asp.Net Core or is necessary use the version for full .NET framework?

Thank you.

issue.title: Production use of SignalR for Asp.Net Core
issue.body:
Hello, 

I would like to ask about production use of SignalR. I want to use the SignalR in the production and is it possible use the latest version of SignalR for Asp.Net Core or is necessary use the version for full .NET framework?

Thank you.

comment.body:
David, 
Is there a place to check or subscribe to when Alpha is out?

issue.title: SignalR server in UWP
issue.body:
I have a desktop application that acts as a SignalR server using ASPNET core self hosted through Owin. I am currently using project Centenial (desktop bridge) to try to deploy the app to the windows store. As you might know this requires MS techs to approve your app. They've told me that the Microsoft store doesn't allow admin privileges although they do allow full trust apps and told me I can't self host.

Is there a way for SignalR server to run on UWP or is there a version of it made for UWP or is this technology not possible for Windows Store apps.

The problem I encountered is that the version labeled with SignalR-rel-2.0.0 can not be built. I ran the build.cmd /t:Restore command, and it gave me the following output: 

[Output](https://gist.github.com/gabor182/d3279703f442cd23a5ceb2bbac46cbbf)

Where can these missing packages be found? If some additional package feeder is needed, then it would be wise to put its url into the readme file (or the build script could automatically update the package source list if a nuget.exe location is given in a command arg)
Is there any way to have a .NET Core 2.0 compatible version of SignalR?

comment.body:
@davidfowl By the way, what is your versioning strategy for SignalR?
I would hope that it would match the version of ASP.NET Core that it is running on top of.

So, v2.0.0-alpha1 would be the first release.

I understand that it is weird from an engineering point of view, but it would make a lot more sense for end-users (I remember the whole confusing with the versions for .NET Core 1.x, .NET Standard 1.x, etc).

Actually, considering that this library lives in the `Microsoft.AspNetCore` namespace, I think it also makes sense from an engineering point of view.

issue.body:
This is my first comment here, so first of all let me thank you all the hard work you put into this library!

[Output](https://gist.github.com/gabor182/d3279703f442cd23a5ceb2bbac46cbbf)

Where can these missing packages be found? If some additional package feeder is needed, then it would be wise to put its url into the readme file (or the build script could automatically update the package source list if a nuget.exe location is given in a command arg)
Is there any way to have a .NET Core 2.0 compatible version of SignalR?

comment.body:
SignalR rel/2.0.0 isn't a thing. In fact the branch should be deleted as it means nothing (since nothing shipped).

We're preparing for an alpha of SignalR Core (1.0.0-alpha1) on top of ASP.NET Core 2.0 (the only version that will run on ASP.NET Core 2.0) next week. Here's a sample on how to run it today https://github.com/davidfowl/SignalRCoreAlphaSample.
